Body:
BC-PHOTO-FULL-UPDATE-NYT 
   ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving Friday, 09/03/99. Photo
clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's
PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo
Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at
305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling
(888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT31) NEW YORK -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- SUB-LABOR-DAY-EXODUS, 09-03
-- People wait for their trains at a packed Pennsylvania Station on
Friday. Millions of Americans travelled on Friday to take advantage
of the long Labor Day weekend which is traditinally seen as the
last weekend of summer. (Nancy Siesel/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT30) UNDATED -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5 --
RUSSIA-BANK-3, 09-03 -- Now you see it, now you pocket it: Graft,
of course, is no novelty in Russia. It is as old as the czars and
was a hallmark of the old Soviet bureaucracy. But the oceans of
Western cash that have washed through Russia in recent years,
combined with scandal-plagued efforts to privatize state-owned
companies, have created an unprecedented ability for the country's
business and political elite to enrich themselves. (Tony
Cenicola/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT29) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- FUNDRAISING-LETTER, 09-03
-- Senator Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., in his office during a 1997
interview. In a recently mailed letter soliciting funds, McConnell,
the chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, said
a ``generous emergency gift of $25 or more'' would help Senate
Republicans defend the United States against a nuclear missile
launched by North Korea. He said the donations will enable Senate
Republicans ``to do what President Clinton will not: preserve,
protect and defend the United States of America.'' (Andrea
Mohin/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT28) TOMSK, Russia -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5
-- RUSSIA-BANK-2, 09-03 -- Residents of the Siberian city of Tomsk
are upset about the layoffs of tens of thousands at Tomskneft, one
of Yukos' biggest oil units and the city's main employer. Some
investors in Yukos subsidiaries are also angry at the company.
(James Hill/New York Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT27) UNDATED -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- GUNS-GOVS, 09-03 -- Since
the shootings at Columbine High School last April, Gov. Bill Owens
of Colorado, right, has advocated new gun control measures. He
discussed these measures recently at a meeting with Colorado
business leaders. (Kevin Moloney/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT26) NEWTON, Mass. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- BOSTON-UHAUL, 09-03 --
Wayne Richard, left, helps his daughter Kerri Ann move into her new
apartment on Monday. In the background is a truck leased to Carmel
Movers who are moving a client out to Cambridge, Mass. Until Labor
Day weekend is over, only foolhardy motorists venture into Boston's
student-filled neighborhoods where rental trucks take over control
of the streets. (Evan Richman/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT25) MALULA, Syria -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- SYRIA-LANGUAGE-2,
09-03 -- Rev. Fayez Frejat, a Greek Catholic priest, inside St.
Sergius' Church, built around the fourth century to honor soldiers
slain by a Roman emperor because of their beliefs. Frejat delights
visitors by reciting the Lord's Prayer in Aramaic even though he
cannot speak the language, having been assigned to Malula just a
few years ago. Aramaic, the language spoken by Jesus, has endured
in this region for nearly 3,000 years. (Courtney Kealy/New York
Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT24) MALULA, Syria -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- SYRIA-LANGUAGE-1,
09-03 -- Mikhail Hala, 75, speaks Aramaic for passing Kuwaiti
tourists. The Syrian capital of Damascus lies just 45 minutes away
but linguistically, Malula is still a place unto itself. Insulated
by isolation and nurtured by pride, Aramaic, the language spoken by
Jesus, has endured in this region for nearly 3,000 years. (Courtney
Kealy/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT23) WHITE PLAINS, New York -- Sept. 3, 1999 --
GOTTI-SENTENCE, 09-03 -- John ``Junior'' Gotti leaves court after
his sentencing on Friday. The 35-year-old Gotti, considered his
dad's successor as head of the once-mighty Gambino crime family,
received nearly 6 years in federal prison after calmly telling a
federal judge he accepted responsibility for his crimes. Gotti, who
will begin his sentence on October 18, had pleaded guilty in April
to charges of bribery, extortion, gambling and fraud. (Joyce
Dopkeen/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT22) CALHOUN, Ga. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5
-- MILLENNIUM-REVIVAL-COX, 09-03 -- Lavern Millsapps, left, sits
near others claiming to have been overcome by the Holy Spirit
during Sunday worship at the East Calhoun Church of God. For 150
weeks now, in lengthy services that begin with enthusiastic singing
and end with people literally lying on the floor, this church has
been hit hard by the Holy Spirit. Or by the devil, say some
critics, or simple mass hysteria. (Ben Gray/Cox News Service)

   (NYT21) NEW YORK -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- TEN-USOPEN-2, 09-03 -- The
war of words between Martina Hingis and the Williams clan - Venus,
Serena and Papa Richard - calmed down after a kiss-and-make-up
meeting staged by the WTA Tour to defuse the feud. The top-ranked
Hingis gave Richard Williams an autographed T-shirt, and he gave
her a hug and a kiss, after she reached the fourth round of the
U.S. Open with a 6-4, 6-2 victory Friday over Sandra Kloesel.
(Chang W. Lee/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT20) NEW YORK -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- TEN-USOPEN-1, 09-03 --
Seventh-seeded American Todd Martin advanced to the third round of
the U.S. Open on Friday with a four-set victory over compatriot
Richey Reneberg. The 29-year-old Martin, who barely survived a
first-round five-setter, defeated Reneberg 6-4, 6-3, 3-6, 6-1.
(Chang W. Lee/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT19) NEW YORK -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5 --
NITEOUT-DOUEIRI-BEIRUT, 09-03 -- Ziad Doueiri, a Lebanese-born
filmmaker, holding court at Kush. His first feature, ``West
Beirut,'' is a coming-of-age story set in Beirut at war, circa
1975. It opened on Friday in New York and Los Angeles. (Linda
Rosier/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT18) NEW YORK -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5 --
OBSCURE-FASHION-4, 09-03 -- Cargo pants from Maharishi, a London
label. The quest for few-of-a-kind fashion is no longer limited to
high-priced designer wares. It has trickled down from Madison
Avenue to neighborhoods below Houston Street, and in the outer
boroughs, where fans of street wear chase limited-circulation goods
from mass brands. (David Corio/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT17) NEW YORK -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5 --
OBSCURE-FASHION-3, 09-03 -- The longtime graffiti artist Futura
2000 owns Recon on the Lower East Side, the only American store to
sell clothes from A Bathing Ape, an obscure Japanese label that
does no advertising. ``It's not about selling as much as you can,''
he says. ``If an item gets popular you make hundreds not
thousands.'' (Chester Higgins Jr./New York Times Photo)

   (NYT16) NEW YORK -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5 --
OBSCURE-FASHION-2, 09-03 -- If mainstream America deems an item
ugly, then it is wanted by Haime Kedmi, the owner of Transit, a
street-wear store. Gingerly he selects a Nike Air Lava Dome sneaker
with a bright orange swoosh and a rounded, reinforced toe that
gives it the look of a corrective shoe. ``Aren't they hideous?''
Kedmi says proudly. ``They're one of our most popular models.''
(Jeffery A. Salter/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT15) NEW YORK -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5 --
OBSCURE-FASHION-1, 09-03 -- Eric Kvatek, a New York photographer,
is one of many young shoppers who are fanatic about hard-to-find
street wear. He discovered his first pair of Nike Air Max 95s in
the Midwest. The sneakers, which he is wearing, caught on after
they were discontinued. (Jeffery A. Salter/New York Times Photo)
LITE

   (NYT14) UNION CITY, N.J. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN.,
SEPT. 5 -- LATIN-FASHION-GUAYABERA, 09-03 -- Three versions of
guayaberas, a hot weather standby in Latin lands, from El Waterloo
in Union City, which sells them. A favorite on the domino circuit
forever, the shirt has now been appropriated by young lovers of
things Latin, styling themselves for ``la vida loca,'' the crazy
life promised by Ricky Martin on MTV. (Jeffery A. Salter/New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT13) CANTON, Mass. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- REEBOK-SLUMP-BOS,
09-03 -- While competitors like Nike, New Balance, and Saucony are
showing enough evidence of growth for some analysts to proclaim the
beginning of the end of hard times for manufacturers of athletic
footwear, Reebok remains listless. Shortly after Labor Day, Reebok
officials confirmed that they will announce layoffs, even as the
company proceeds with construction of a new $51 million
headquarters in Canton. (David L Ryan/Boston Globe Photo)

   (NYT12) NEW YORK -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5 --
RUSSIA-BANK, 09-03 -- Mikhail Khodorkovsky, chairman of Rosprom, a
Russian conglomerate, agrees that rampant stealing is certainly bad
for Russia. ``If what we're talking about is sucking the lifeblood
out of industry into some personal holdings so that this money will
no longer be plowed back into the company, if we word it that way,
then yes, it's a huge problem,'' says Khodorkovsky, 35. (Fred R.
Conrad/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT11) UNDATED -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5 --
BIZ-WORLDBANK-BAIRD, 09-03 -- Out of pinstripes and in the field,
Mark Baird, the man with the unbankerly beard, tours a school in
crisis-racked Indonesia, where he is the World Bank's country
director. Baird, 48, says that as an economist for the bank in
Jakarta in the late 1980s, he followed the old style. ``We prided
ourselves on working behind the scenes, with the government,'' he
says. ``Now, I think we should have spoken out on corruption.''
(World Bank/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT10) WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Sept. 3, 1999 --
FL-PLANECRASH-COX, 09-03 -- Rescue personnel and investigators at
the scene of an airplane crash on Friday. The twin-engine
Beechcraft King Air BE-90 clipped a building and crashed into
flames while trying to make an emergency landing in the dark early
today, killing the eight people aboard. (Lannis Waters/Palm Beach
Post) LITE

   (NYT9) BEIJING -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- CHINA-ANNIVERSARY-COX, 09-03
-- Pedestrians walk down a renovated Wangfujing Street. The
recently renovated glitzy shopping district is a centerpiece for
the 50th anniversary of China's Communist revolution on October 1.
(Joseph P. Albright/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT8) MOUNT OLIVE, N.C. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN.,
SEPT. 5 -- CHANGING-IMMIGRANT-3-COX, 09-03 -- Esperanza Valdez, 41,
lives in one of the homes provided by Carolina Turkeys with her
five children. She pays $320 a month in rent, plus the electric
bill. ``Here, I feel good. I have a job, a safe place to live -
things I didn't have before,'' she said, gazing down at her
brightly colored dining room tablecloth. (George Bridges/Cox News
Service Photo)

   (NYT7) MOUNT OLIVE, N.C. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN.,
SEPT. 5 -- CHANGING-IMMIGRANT-2-COX, 09-03 -- Juvencio Peralta,
Jr., manages the 120 low-cost housing units offered to Latino
workers at Carolina Turkeys. Peralta helps make the transition to
life in North Carolina less of culture shock by organizing Latino
festivals, planning soccer tournaments and helping residents
understand local and state health care and education issues.
(George Bridges/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT6) MOUNT OLIVE, N.C. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN.,
SEPT. 5 -- CHANGING-IMMIGRANT-1-COX, 09-03 -- Workers process
turkeys at Carolina Turkeys, the largest turkey processing plant in
the nation. Latinos make up 65 percent of the plant's work force.
(George Bridges/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT5) CLAYTON, N.C. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5
-- CHANGING-SOUTH-2-COX, 09-03 -- Elcoterio Verdugo carries a
bundle of tobacco leaves through a field as he and others work
picking the leaves near Mount Olive. North Carolina's large cities,
small towns and rural areas are being transformed as Hispanic
professionals, entrepreneurs and laborers become a growing part of
the state's booming economy. (George Bridges/Cox News Service
Photo)

   (NYT4) CLAYTON, N.C. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5
-- CHANGING-SOUTH-1-COX, 09-03 -- Antonio Altucer, from Campeche,
Mexico, picks tobacco in a field near Mount Olive, N.C. Altucer,
39, said he had arrived in North Carolina just two days earlier,
after a long journey from Campeche in southern Mexico. ``Two days
and there's already work,'' he said. ``This is a happy place.''
(George Bridges/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT3) OCEAN CITY, Md. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT.
5 -- SEA-FAMILY-2-COX, 09-03 -- Chad Stewart, 16, shows how he
tried to steer the Stewart's boat, the Jolly Joyce, after the
rudder broke. His mother, Deb, watches Chad demonstrate how he
attached a broken screwdriver to the rudder stem and used his feet
to push on the rudder to try and keep the boat on course. (Rick
McKay/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT2) OCEAN CITY, Md. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT.
5 -- SEA-FAMILY-1-COX, 09-03 -- The Stewart family, from left,
Rick, Chad, 16, Deb, and Mischa, 12, on their boat, the Jolly
Joyce. Last Tuesday the U.S. Coast Guard towed the Stewart's boat
to Ocean City ending reports that they had been missing. (Rick
McKay/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT1) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- WACO-RENO, 09-03 --
Attorney General Janet Reno answers questions from reporters about
the 1993 Branch Davidian siege during her weekly press briefing at
the Justice Department Friday morning. Ms. Reno said she will find
a person who is free of ``conflicts of interest and will be
well-received'' to head an independent investigation into why it
took the FBI six years to acknowledge its use of the pyrotechnic
tear-gas canisters. (Justin Lane/New York Times Photo)

   The New York Times News Service
Text:
ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving Friday, 09/03/99. Photo
clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's
PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo
Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at
305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling
(888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.

(George Bridges/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT5) CLAYTON, N.C. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5
-- CHANGING-SOUTH-2-COX, 09-03 -- Elcoterio Verdugo carries a
bundle of tobacco leaves through a field as he and others work
picking the leaves near Mount Olive. North Carolina's large cities,
small towns and rural areas are being transformed as Hispanic
professionals, entrepreneurs and laborers become a growing part of
the state's booming economy. (George Bridges/Cox News Service
Photo)

   (NYT4) CLAYTON, N.C. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT. 5
-- CHANGING-SOUTH-1-COX, 09-03 -- Antonio Altucer, from Campeche,
Mexico, picks tobacco in a field near Mount Olive, N.C. Altucer,
39, said he had arrived in North Carolina just two days earlier,
after a long journey from Campeche in southern Mexico. ``Two days
and there's already work,'' he said. ``This is a happy place.''
(George Bridges/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT3) OCEAN CITY, Md. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT.
5 -- SEA-FAMILY-2-COX, 09-03 -- Chad Stewart, 16, shows how he
tried to steer the Stewart's boat, the Jolly Joyce, after the
rudder broke. His mother, Deb, watches Chad demonstrate how he
attached a broken screwdriver to the rudder stem and used his feet
to push on the rudder to try and keep the boat on course. (Rick
McKay/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT2) OCEAN CITY, Md. -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., SEPT.
5 -- SEA-FAMILY-1-COX, 09-03 -- The Stewart family, from left,
Rick, Chad, 16, Deb, and Mischa, 12, on their boat, the Jolly
Joyce. Last Tuesday the U.S. Coast Guard towed the Stewart's boat
to Ocean City ending reports that they had been missing. (Rick
McKay/Cox News Service Photo)

   (NYT1) WASHINGTON -- Sept. 3, 1999 -- WACO-RENO, 09-03 --
Attorney General Janet Reno answers questions from reporters about
the 1993 Branch Davidian siege during her weekly press briefing at
the Justice Department Friday morning. Ms. Reno said she will find
a person who is free of ``conflicts of interest and will be
well-received'' to head an independent investigation into why it
took the FBI six years to acknowledge its use of the pyrotechnic
tear-gas canisters. (Justin Lane/New York Times Photo)
